questions.question: What is the first law of motion, also known as the Law of Inertia?
options: An object at rest will remain in motion unless acted upon by an external force.
A net force acting on an object will result in a change in its momentum.
The force required to move an object is directly proportional to its mass and acceleration.
Every action has an equal and opposite reaction.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes Newton's second law of motion?
options: F = ma, where F is the net force acting on an object.
A force applied to an object will always cause it to accelerate.
The more massive an object is, the greater its inertia.
An object at rest will remain in rest unless acted upon by an external force.

questions.question: A car accelerates from 0 to 60 km/h in 10 seconds. What can be concluded about the net force acting on the car?
options: It is negligible.
It must be constant throughout the acceleration period.
The force is directly proportional to the mass of the car.
None of these options.

questions.question: A person throws a ball upward with an initial velocity of 15 m/s. What will happen to its velocity as it reaches the highest point?
options: Its velocity will increase.
Its velocity will decrease.
Its velocity will remain constant.
The information is insufficient.

questions.question: According to Newton's third law of motion, what happens when a car pushes a wall?
options: The car exerts an equal force on the wall and experiences a larger force in return.
The car exerts a smaller force on the wall than it experiences itself.
The car does not exert any force on the wall.
There is no interaction between the car and the wall.

questions.question: A block of wood with a mass of 2 kg is moving at a speed of 5 m/s when it collides with another identical block. What can be concluded about the collision?
options: Both blocks will stick together after the collision.
The first block will come to rest while the second block gains a velocity of 10 m/s.
There is insufficient information to determine what happens during the collision.
None of these options.

questions.question: A force of 20 N acts on an object with a mass of 5 kg for a period of 10 seconds. What will be its final velocity after the force has been applied?
options: 0 m/s.
4 m/s.
The information is insufficient to determine the final velocity.
None of these options.

questions.question: A ball rolls up a frictionless ramp with an initial velocity of 10 m/s. What can be concluded about its velocity at the highest point?
options: It will increase as it reaches the top.
It will remain constant throughout the motion.
The information is insufficient to determine what happens during the motion.
None of these options.

questions.question: What would happen if all external forces acting on an object were suddenly removed?
options: Its velocity would decrease due to air resistance.
Its velocity would remain constant while its acceleration becomes zero.
Its velocity and acceleration both become zero.
None of these options.

questions.question: What is the net effect on an object's motion when two forces acting in opposite directions are applied to it?
options: The forces will cancel each other out.
The force with a greater magnitude will dominate the motion.
There will be no change in its motion.
None of these options.
